user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
```c
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments need not be investigated for MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13 because they either already use const where applicable or involve objects that must be modifiable. Specifically: the function parameter is declared as const OS_object_token_t * (so the incoming token pointer is const-qualified); the calls to fcntl use integer values and do not involve pointer-to-data that could be const-qualified; impl->selectable is explicitly assigned (so the referenced record must be mutable and impl cannot be const); the global OS_impl_filehandle_table is declared as a mutable array of records (so returning a non-const pointer to its elements can be necessary); strerror(errno) returns a char * from the C library and is used only for diagnostic output; OS_DEBUG is a no-op macro here. Therefore these parts do not present additional concerns under Rule 8.13.
